Discharge.origin: [a formal instrument…may be discharged by either cancellation or surrender "J. D. Calamari and J. M. Perillo"]

sub_terms.a: to relieve of a duty under an instrument (as a contract or a negotiable instrument)to render (an instrument) no longer enforceable [a formal instrument…may beby either cancellation or surrender "J. D. Calamari and J. M. Perillo"]

2.definition: the state of being discharged or released [a party seeking a total ]

sub_terms.b: to release from service or duty [ a jury] [ a witness]

4 a.definition: to get rid of (as a debt or obligation) by performing an appropriate action

sub_terms.b: to fulfill a requirement for [evidence which is required to the burden of going forward "W. R. LaFave and A. W. Scott, Jr."]

5.definition: to order (a legislative committee) to end consideration of a bill in order to bring it before the house for action

1 a.definition: the act of relieving of something that burdens or oppresses

sub_terms.b: something that discharges or releasesa certification of or a document proving release or payment

3.definition: release from confinement [ordering a conditional of the alien on habeas corpus ""]

4.definition: the act of removing an obligation or liability (as by payment of a debt or performance of a duty)

5 a.definition: a dismissal from employment or office

constructive discharge.definition: discharge of an employee effected by making the employee's working conditions so intolerable that he or she reasonably feels compelled to resign

retaliatory discharge.definition: a wrongful discharge that is done in retaliation for an employee's conduct (as reporting an employer's criminal activity) and that clearly violates public policy

wrongful discharge.definition: discharge of an employee for illegal reasons or for reasons that are contrary to public policy (as in retaliation for the employee's refusal to engage in unlawful activity)

sub_terms.b: a release from service or duty
